src:
Istra, ujeta v bernardinskih arkadah
Ob pešpoti med Piranom in Portorožem so v starih kamnitih obokih pri nekdanjem samostanu s cerkvijo sv. Bernardina odprli edinstveno razstavo velikih fotografij.
03 Nov 2019, 11:51 by Janez Mužič



Kamnite arkade z istrsko zgodbo FOTO: Brane Maksimovič



Šavrinke na poti na tržaško tržnico FOTO: Ubald Trnkoczy



Ob mestnem vodnjaku FOTO: Ubald Trnkoczy



Razstava govori o stvareh, ki počasi izginjajo, a tudi o ljudeh, ki želijo te vrednote obdržati, pravi Ubald Trnkoczy. FOTO: Janez Mužič



Od začetka je poslanstvo društva Anbot ohranjanje in revitalizacija kulturne ter naravne dediščine, pravi Natalija Planinc. FOTO: Janez Mužič



Nočni pogled na osvetljene bernardinske oboke FOTO: Ubald Trnkoczy



Člani Anbota, ki so spomin na bogato preteklost Istre lovili v naravnem okolju. FOTO: Nataša Fajon


Podporni loki oziroma oboki, ki ščitijo vzpetino, na kateri stojijo ostanki cerkve nekdanjega samostana na Bernardinu, so bili postavljeni okoli leta 1750. Nad njimi so se ohranile le ruševine zvonika s prezbiterijem, ki zdaj sredi turističnega kompleksa Bernardin burijo domišljijo. Samostan in cerkev je dal leta 1452 zgraditi frančiškan sv. Janez Kapistran (1386–1456), potujoči pridigar in spovednik, eden največjih ljudskih govornikov. Močno si je prizadeval, da bi za svetnika razglasili njegovega učitelja in prijatelja Bernarda Sienskega, kar mu je uspelo 1450., ko mu je posvetil cerkev in samostan. Ukinili so jo leta 1806, avstrijska vojska pa je samostan spremenila v trdnjavo za obrambo Piranskega zaliva. Objekt je bil porušen ob gradnji hotelskega kompleksa leta 1974, ohranili pa so ostanke zvonika. Pod razgledno ploščadjo, od koder se odpira čudovit razgled na Piranski zaliv, je 11 mogočnih kamnitih obokov, pod katerimi ob morju teče ena najbolj priljubljenih sprehajalnih poti med Portorožem in Piranom.
Prizori iz istrskega zaledja


Šavrinke na poti na tržaško tržnico FOTO: Ubald Trnkoczy

Do nedavnega zaraščeni oboki marsikoga pripravijo, da se ob njih ustavi, saj pozornost pritegnejo velike barvne fotografije. Na njih so upodobljeni prizori iz življenja istrskega zaledja: šavrinke, ki nosijo pridelke v mesto, perice ob piranskem vodnjaku, moški, ki so zatopljeni v igranje more, obiralci oljk, delo v torklji, ulov ribičev, gojenje artičok, obiranje ruja, ki so ga uporabljali za barvanje tkanin, in podobni motivi. Razstavo z naslovom Male štorije naše dediščine so odprli ob Dnevih evropske kulturne dediščine in je že pritegnila pozornost sprehajalcev. Pobudo zanjo je skupaj z avtorjem fotografij Ubaldom Trnkoczyem dalo piransko Društvo Anbot.»Člani društva so ljudje, ki jim ni vseeno za naš kraj, ljudi, preteklost in prihodnost, pa čeprav za to ne prejmejo plačila. Skupna jim je želja narediti nekaj lepega in dobrega. Pri snemanju je sodelovalo 70 ljudi, mnogi so za to vzeli dopust, sami so izdelali kostume in se na lokacije po Istri pripeljali s svojimi vozili. Spoznali so vrednost zgodbe in jo podprli,« je o nastanku velikih fotografij v sodelovanju s člani Anbota povedal Trnkoczy.
Raznovrstni krožki
Društvo Anbot je postalo že slovenski fenomen. Nastalo je leta 2003 in šteje okoli 30 članov. Njegovo poslanstvo je ohranjanje ter revitalizacija kulturne in naravne dediščine, ponujajo raznovrstne krožke in neformalne oblike izobraževanja odraslih, kot so restavratorstvo, pletenje košar, izdelovanje mozaikov, kamnoseštvo, kaligrafija ipd. Vse se je začelo z idejo Natalije Planinc in njenim sodelovanjem s soustanoviteljem društva, pokojnim Leopoldom Belcem, ki je bogato znanje o restavratorstvu prvi predajal članom in sprožil pravi razcvet te dejavnosti v Piranu. Krožek živi še danes in marsikateri dom krasijo obnovljene starine, ki bi bile sicer zavržene.


Ob mestnem vodnjaku FOTO: Ubald Trnkoczy

»Razstava je odraz našega minulega dela, ki se je začelo z restavratorstvom. Ljudje imajo doma veliko starin, mojstrov za restavriranje pa ni. K sreči smo imeli našega Poldeta, ki je s svojim motom vse se da res vse znal. Iz teh krožkov je leta 2004 nastalo prvo sodelovanje z Dnevi evropske kulturne dediščine. Vsako leto je nova tema za nas nov izziv. Zgodbo, ki smo jo poimenovali Piranska podstrešja pripovedujejo, smo izpeljali tako odlično, da so se nacionalni Dnevi evropske kulturne dediščine naslednje leto odprli pri nas v Piranu. Takrat nam je na temo povezanosti snovne in nesnovne dediščine uspelo povezati kar 500 sodelujočih. Od takrat jih organiziramo redno,« pravi o Anbotu dolgoletna predsednica in dobitnica Steletovega priznanja Natalija Planinc.
Nova vrednost obokov
Ker je v njihovih vrstah tudi Ubald Trnkoczy, so v okviru Dnevov evropske kulturne dediščine 2017 v izvirnih ambientih nastale fotografije, s katerimi so oplemenitili spomin na bogato preteklost naših krajev. Prvič so bile postavljene na ogled v križnem hodniku minoritskega samostana v Piranu, nato pa v sklopu 25-letnice delovanja študijskih krožkov v Sloveniji še v Jakopičevem drevoredu v Tivoliju, v Pretorski palači in na obzidju ob morju nasproti potniškega terminala v Kopru.


Člani Anbota, ki so spomin na bogato preteklost Istre lovili v naravnem okolju. FOTO: Nataša Fajon

Od 18 fotografij iz serije jih je v obokih devet natisnjenih na platno v formatu 3,1 x 3,1 m, poleg pa sta še dve platni z informacijami o razstavi v več jezikih. Tam so tudi QR-kode, ki pomagajo pri razlagi prizora na fotografiji. »Vrednost projekta je v tem, da smo ta prostor izkoristili za nov namen in mu dali novo vrednost. Zdaj so oboki ponoči osvetljeni, kar jim daje čisto drugo arhitektonsko podobo,« dodaja Trnkoczy. Vrnitev v istrsko preteklost so na odprtju pod svojim obokom pospremili člani Anbota, ki so ponovno upodabljali svoje značilne like s fotografij, ter še številni drugi. Manjkala ni nacionalna koordinatorica Dnevov evropske kulturne dediščine Nataša Gorenc, ki pravi, da smo v sklopu teh prireditev Slovenci evropski prvaki po številu dogodkov in obiskovalcev na njih. In dodala, da brez Anbota ti dnevi ne bi bili taki, kot so.
text:
Istria trapped in Bernardine arcades
Along the footpath between Piran and Portorož, in the old stone arches at the former monastery with the church of Sv. Bernardina opened a unique exhibition of great photographs.
03 Nov 2019, 11:51 by Janez Male



Stone arcades with an Istrian story PHOTO: Brane Maksimovic



Shavrinka on her way to the Market Square PHOTO: Ubald Trnkoczy



Near the city well PHOTO: Ubald Trnkoczy



The show is about things that are slowly disappearing, but also about people who want to retain those values, says Ubald Trnkoczy. PHOTO: Janez Muzic



From the beginning, the mission of the Anbot Society is to preserve and revitalize the cultural and natural heritage, says Natalija Planinc. PHOTO: Janez Muzic



Night view of illuminated Bernardine arches PHOTO: Ubald Trnkoczy



Anbot members who hunted the memory of Istria's rich past in natural surroundings. PHOTO: Natasha Fajon


Support arches or vaults protecting the hill on which the remains of the church of the former Bernardine monastery stand were erected around 1750. Above them, only the ruins of the bell tower with the presbytery, which are now in the midst of the Bernardin tourist complex, have been rousing. The monastery and the church were built in 1452 by the Franciscan St. John Kapistran (1386-1456), a traveling preacher and confessor, one of the greatest folk speakers. He worked hard to proclaim his teacher and friend Bernard Siensky as a saint, which he succeeded in 1450 when he was consecrated to the church and the monastery. It was abolished in 1806, and the Austrian army turned the monastery into a fortress for the defense of the Bay of Piran. The building was demolished when the hotel complex was built in 1974 and the remains of the bell tower have been preserved. Below the viewing platform, which offers a magnificent view of the Bay of Piran, there are 11 mighty stone vaults under which one of the most popular walking paths between Portorož and Piran runs along the sea.
Scenes from the Istrian hinterland


Shavrinka on her way to the Market Square PHOTO: Ubald Trnkoczy

Until recently, overgrown vaults have prepared many to stop by, as large color photographs attract attention. They depict scenes from the life of the Istrian hinterland: chevrons carrying produce to the city, feathers by the Piran fountain, men immersed in sea playing, olive harvesters, working in a torquay, catching fishermen, cultivating artichokes, picking ore used for dyeing fabrics, and similar motifs. The exhibition entitled The Little Stories of Our Heritage was opened on the occasion of the European Cultural Heritage Days and has already attracted the attention of walkers. The initiative was co-sponsored by the Anbot Society of Piran, together with photo author Ubaldo Trnkoczy. "The members of the association are people who care about our place, people, past and future, even though they do not receive payment for it. They have a common desire to do something nice and good. 70 people took part in the shooting, many took a vacation, made costumes themselves and drove to locations across Istria with their vehicles. They realized the value of the story and supported it, "said Trnkoczy about the creation of large photographs in collaboration with Anbot members.
Various circles
The Anbot Society has already become a Slovenian phenomenon. It was formed in 2003 and has about 30 members. Its mission is to preserve and revitalize the cultural and natural heritage, offering a variety of circles and non-formal forms of adult education, such as restoration, basketry, mosaic making, stonemasonry, calligraphy, etc. It all started with the idea of Natalia Planinc and her collaboration with the co-founder of the society, the late Leopold Belec, who first passed the rich knowledge of restoration to the members and triggered a real boom of this activity in Piran. The circle still lives today and many homes are adorned with restored antiques that would otherwise have been discarded.


Near the city well PHOTO: Ubald Trnkoczy

“The exhibition is a reflection of our past work that began with restoration. People have a lot of antiques at home and there are no restoration masters. Thankfully, we had our Poldet, who knew everything with his motto. From these circles, the first cooperation with the Days of European Cultural Heritage was made in 2004. Each year, a new topic is a new challenge for us. The story, called the Piran Attic, is told so well that the National Days of European Cultural Heritage opened next year in Piran. At that time, as many as 500 participants were able to connect the subject of material and intangible heritage. Since then, we have been organizing them on a regular basis, "says longtime president and Stelet Award winner Natalia Planinc about Anbot.
New vaults value
Because Ubald Trnkoczy is one of their kind, the European Cultural Heritage Days 2017 has created original photographs in the original ambience to enhance the memory of the rich past of our places. They were first displayed in the crosswalk of the Minorite monastery in Piran, and then as part of the 25th anniversary of the study circles in Slovenia, the Jakopič avenue in Tivoli, the Praetorian Palace and the walls by the sea opposite the passenger terminal in Koper.


Anbot members who hunted the memory of Istria's rich past in natural surroundings. PHOTO: Natasha Fajon

Of the 18 photographs in the series, nine are printed on canvases in 3.1 x 3.1 m format in arches, plus two canvases with information about the exhibition in several languages. There are also QR codes to help explain the scene in the photo. “The value of the project is that we used this space for a new purpose and gave it new value. Now the vaults are illuminated at night, giving them a completely different architectural appearance, "adds Trnkoczy. The return to the Istrian past was celebrated at the opening under its vault by members of Anbot, who re-portrayed their typical characters from photographs and many others. Missing is not the national coordinator of the European Cultural Heritage Days, Natasa Gorenc, who says that as part of these events, Slovenes are European champions in terms of the number of events and visitors to them. And she added that without Anbot these days would not be what they are.
